events.text:
I awoke to my phone ringing.

The classic ringchime cut through the sleep deprivation and whiskey like a cheap butcher's knife through gristle, with a painful but unrelenting drag that pulled me from the mercy of sleep.

It had been a long night, and far from typical. Investigations, arguments, loose ends and dead ones, threats, promises, and the spinning lights of Las Borpas gleaming in the vicious dark... those were the only boys I had a night out with, anymore.
The wife had been asleep when I got home, so I consoled myself with my mistress instead, the cheapest and dirtiest whiskey I could find. It was in her arms that I finally found rest.
But now, the phone. I shook my head like a tired old dog coming in from the rain, and answered. Quiet, so as not to wake the wife, who definitely exists.
John Souls, PD.
Mister Souls, this is the Las Borpas Police Department. We'd like to request your cooperation at a crime scene.
I checked the clock. Not even 8 AM on a Saturday. Little Billy wouldn't even be awake.
This early?
Crimes happen at night, Mister Souls, we find them in the day. You know the drill.
Same old song, same old dance, and the Las Borpas PD was a partner I'd taken to the floor more than once.
Scene?
Thoroughbred Estate.
Should have known. That's just the way this city played, sometimes.
I fumbled on the floor near my bed and found my whiskey with the cap off, a precious reservoir pooled in the bottom. I took a drink to clear my head.
Mister Souls?
Yeah. I'm coming.
I hung up, then called a cab. I wasn't driving anywhere with this hangover.
On the way over, I checked my phone.
Cryptic texts from leads and contacts.
News reports.
Cat videos.

Nothing about Thoroughbred on the news yet though. The LBPD had called me right away, before the paparazzi had a chance to get their greasy little mitts on a keyboard and churn out that brain-candy clickbait they love to peddle.
My stomach churned with a mix of hunger and dread, both as subtle as a shotgun. Nothing in it but booze and the toast I'd still been eating when I ran outside to catch the cab.
That, and the feeling that today was going to be ugly. Didn't need a detective's instinct to know that. Just had to look outside. Barely a [color=#ff0000]drop of color[/color] in the sky.
